instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message:
[FONT=Arial][SIZE=14px]Mid 2009 A1286 with logic board # 820-2523 has green artifacts on LCD. Tried with a 2nd and then a 3rd LCD and then with 2 other LVDS cables and still has green artifacts. So 3 different LCDs and 3 different LVDS cables and all have the same problem.[/SIZE][/FONT]

[FONT=Arial][SIZE=14px]Zero signs of corrosion or liquid on logic board but ran it through the ultrasonic cleaner anyway.[/SIZE][/FONT]

[FONT=Arial][SIZE=14px]Video via Mini DisplayPort looks fine. Switching between the dual graphics has no effect.[/SIZE][/FONT]

[FONT=Arial][SIZE=14px]Ideas? Thanks!

Here's a photo of the green artifacts. They're all down the left side but they appear in other places where there is black.[/SIZE][/FONT]

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message:
No Title

It seems to me like the lcd connector pins probably are unstuck. They are usually stuck with glue, I had the same problem with an 820 2530 2009 lcd screen.
I did this (see picture) and it works well but it is for me for a customer probably you´ll have to glue them again, anyway try first pressing the connector carefully with your finger if the green artifacts are gone doing that, and let us know.

threads.message:
[QUOTE="JorgePayar, post: 824"]It seems to me like the lcd connector pins probably are unstuck. They usually are stuck with glue, I had the same problem with an 820 2530 2009 lcd screen.
I did this (see picture) and it works well but it is for me for a customer probably you´ll have to glue them again, anyway try fist pressing the connector carefully with your finger if the green artifacts are gone doing that, and let us know.[/QUOTE]

I have now tested this with 3 different LCDs and 3 different LVDS cables and the green artifacts are still there.

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message: Tap U9600 with your fingernail and tell me what happens.

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message:
No Title

[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 833"]Tap U9600 with your fingernail and tell me what happens. [/QUOTE]

Tapping to locate a short by Louis Rossmann xD

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message: Cracked ball under the LVDS MUX is the most common cause when the machine gets over 5 years old on these models.

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 833"]Tap U9600 with your fingernail and tell me what happens. [/QUOTE]

That's it! When I tap U9600 the green artifacts come and go. If I apply slight pressure to U9600 the green goes away so long as I hold pressure on it.

That's a small chip, with lots of that adhesive rubber stuff around the edges, any chance of reflowing it or should I move on?

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message: Remove all the glue and reflow.............

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message: Reflow is fine here, this is not a flip chip design, and it is not a chip that gets hot. It is an issue with the balls. Toss flux under and reflow like aprendiz said! Of course remove the edge bonding crap.

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message:
I've never reflowed before and I'm terrified I'll screw something else up but I'm gonna give it a go!

Any pointers as far as temperature of hotair station and how much airflow? I've watched Louis's videos on doing this but would like some hear and air suggestions before I attempt it.

Thanks!

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message: Just practice on dead boards.

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message: I've not had much success reflowing the GMUX. I always end up pulling it and reballing. If you thought the SMC was a bitch then U9600 is a whole new level.

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 926"]I've not had much success reflowing the GMUX. I always end up pulling it and reballing. If you thought the SMC was a bitch then U9600 is a whole new level.[/QUOTE]

Uh oh, Louis and others make it sound like a normal day at work for them to do it, but you say you've not been very successful doing it.

Makes me want to just put a shim on it and let the bottom cover keep pressure on it instead of risking a reflow and potentially ending up with a completely fried chip or some other part of the board stops working!

That's why I asked for heat and airflow settings. I could practice on a dead board but that won't tell me if I've done damage with the reflow, to the MUX chip or other nearby components.

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message:
All of my reflows work. The problem is that you need a preheater or a very strong hot air station because the board has a high thermal mass in that area with the MCP being right under it. If you don't have a preheater just sit it in the oven at 290f for a half hour before you work on it, quickly transport it to your workbench, and reflow.

If it needs reballing, which is only when someone else destroyed it, I don't bother fixing it, it isn't worth the hassle.

Heat and airflow settings are a total waste. My JBC at 420c hits 530c and my weller at 1000f is lucky to do 400c. It won't translate to whatever you are doing. You just have to practice on a donor board.

Here you'll see a student reflow his first U9600 successfully. If Sean can do it, so can you! [URL]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n9FgTfj98TQ[/URL]

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 935"]All of my reflows work. The problem is that you need a preheater or a very strong hot air station because the board has a high thermal mass in that area with the MCP being right under it. If you don't have a preheater just sit it in the oven at 290f for a half hour before you work on it, quickly transport it to your workbench, and reflow.

If it needs reballing, which is only when someone else destroyed it, I don't bother fixing it, it isn't worth the hassle.

Heat and airflow settings are a total waste. My JBC at 420c hits 530c and my weller at 1000f is lucky to do 400c. It won't translate to whatever you are doing. You just have to practice on a donor board.

Here you'll see a student reflow his first U9600 successfully. If Sean can do it, so can you! [url]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n9FgTfj98TQ[/url][/QUOTE]

I've studied that video several times as I prepare to do this. I also understand that different hot air stations will perform very differently.

What I'm looking for, I guess, is more of a general answer, do I set my station for high heat and low air, so as not to blow the tiny solder balls out, or do I go for both high heat AND high air?

It sounds like the idea is to get it hot, quickly, and get out, right?

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message:
420c 75% air. quickly is a subjective term. the board must be warm to the point where it is not absorbing the heat you put on the chip.

heat the chip enough to get solder balls melted, not enough to fuck up the chip. if you can tap it and it moves a tiny bit you're good.

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message: OK, I'm gonna give it a try. Last question, I've never used my toaster oven to preheat a board, is it OK to sit the board on the rack or should I put something under it so the metal rack isn't touching the underside?

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message: metal rack touching it is fine, you are far away from a temperature that will melt solder or hurt anything

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message: How is best way to remove the edge bonding glue? Heat in the oven and peel it off or use hot air station?

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message: Never mind, should have tried a few things myself before asking. Hot air at around 300F and they come right up!

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message: I usually put in the oven at 300f and then use the hot air station around 250c from a distance with tweezers to remove it. It requires patience to do, and calm. No doing this if you had an argument with your girlfriend that day.

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message:
Success! Green artifacts are GONE.  Thanks to everyone for holding my hand as I did my first one. I was super worried about it but then realized that it was apply heat and fix the issue or toss it in the junk pile, so I really had nothing to lose (it's my laptop, they all are, I buy, repair, and resell). I was wary of applying too much heat but I was worried more about NOT applying enough heat and having the green artifacts still be there.

I tried to add [SOLVED] to the title of this thread but it wouldn't let me. Is that something only admins can do?

threads.title: [SOLVED] Green Artifacts on LCD - 820-2523 bad LVDS MUX U9600
threads.message: Glad to hear it!
